speaker: Rob
text: Hello, I'm Rob. Welcome to Six Minute English, where we get together to discuss an interesting topic along with six useful items of vocabulary to wrestle with.

speaker: Catherine
text: Yes, hello I'm Catherine. And today's topic is all about togetherness – because we're talking about going to the gym and why gym membership is becoming increasingly popular. So Rob… do you head off to your local gym after work?

speaker: Rob
text: No – I hate group exercise. I prefer to go for a run on my own. It's free, and I enjoy being outdoors. How about you Catherine?

speaker: Catherine
text: I really like group exercise Rob. I find it's very motivating.

speaker: motivating
text: When something is motivating it makes us want to do something. So what motivates you to go to the gym, Catherine?

speaker: Catherine
text: Well I go because I really like the spin classes.

speaker: Rob
text: Is that where you cycle on the spot while an instructor shouts at you?

speaker: Catherine
text: Well, yes that's the one! If I wasn't in a class, I don't think I would push myself so hard. I need someone to shout at me – to make me go faster and get up those hills.

speaker: push yourselfwork out
text: Good and if you push yourself you force yourself to try harder – you set yourself a challenge. OK, Catherine – well you are part of a growing trend of people who like to work out – or exercise in a gym. So perhaps you can tell me, how many people are members of a gym, here in the UK? Is it…

speaker: push yourselfwork out
text: a) 1 in 2,

speaker: push yourselfwork out
text: b) 1 in 7 or

speaker: Catherine
text: I'm going to go for 1 in 10.

speaker: Rob
text: Well – we'll find out if you chose the right answer later on. Now let's listen to Philip Mills – he runs the sports fitness company Les Mills – named after his father, who was a track and field athlete who represented New Zealand for twenty years. Philip has a theory to explain why group exercise has become so popular in recent years.

speaker: Philip Mills, CEO of Les Mills International
text: As people have become more sedentary they've realised that they need to move for their health. We work about 35% more hours than we used to work in the 60s. And people are too busy to play sports. Society has become fragmented and a lot of the things that used to bring people together don't exist anymore. But, you know, we're tribal animals – pack animals – and the gym has been one of the things that helps people to commune.

speaker: Catherine
text: Yes our sedentary lifestyles! We do all spend too much time sitting down, don't we, Rob?

speaker: Rob
text: Yes, and according to Philip we're probably spending more time sitting down than we used to because we're working a lot more.

speaker: Catherine
text: And because we're busier with work, we have less time to take exercise.

speaker: Rob
text: So why are we choosing to go to the gym these days, rather than heading down to the park to play football? Philip Mills thinks it's because society has become fragmented – and we're losing the social connectedness that made it easy to get together and take exercise.

speaker: fragmentedtribe
text: And fragmented means broken up into small pieces, by the way. The thing is, we miss that social connectedness – that feeling of belonging to a group – because we are essentially tribal animals. And a tribe is a group of people who live together and they share the same language and the same culture.

speaker: Rob
text: So even now most of us have left tribal society behind, we still want to feel like we're part of a group that we can commune with – which means to get close to someone or something.

speaker: Catherine
text: But the question is Rob, does group exercise at the gym actually succeed in connecting us with other people?

speaker: Rob
text: Well, Philip Mills thinks in the future we'll be cycling inside a video game using computer graphics – you know, visiting other planets, travelling to different times…

speaker: Catherine
text: Wow! But people will then be communing with a computer Rob, not really with each other?

speaker: Rob
text: I'm afraid so. And you won't even have a real instructor barking instructions at you!

speaker: Catherine
text: Well I suppose a computer will have a virtual instructor who will also be equally motivating!

speaker: Rob
text: Yes, I expect so. Now, remember I asked you, Catherine: How many people are members of a gym, here in the UK?

speaker: Catherine
text: I do remember you asking me that Rob and I said 1 in 10.

speaker: Rob
text: And you were wrong, I'm afraid! Figures collected by Leisure Data Base, a company that has audited the fitness industry for fifteen years, show that one in seven of the UK population is a member of a gym. And more and more will be signing up. Total membership could soon exceed ten million for the first time.

speaker: Catherine
text: Wow!

speaker: Rob
text: OK, now let's talk through the vocabulary items we heard today. Number one is 'motivating' – meaning something that makes us want to do something – 'I don't find the idea of cycling in a small room very motivating.'

speaker: Catherine
text: Now number two – If you push yourself, you force yourself to try harder – 'It's important to push yourself if you want to do well in your exams.'

speaker: Rob
text: Good advice there, Catherine. Next up is 'work out' – which means to exercise in order to improve your health and fitness. For example, 'Catherine works out three times a week by cycling on the spot.' Our fourth word is 'fragmented' or broken up into small pieces. For example, 'I suffer from fragmented sleep. I wake up five or six times a night.'

speaker: Catherine
text: Poor you! Alright, number four is 'tribal' – and the noun is 'tribe' – a group of people who live together and share the same language and culture.

speaker: Rob
text: 'Football fans often wear the tribal colours of the team they support – some paint their faces too.'

speaker: Catherine
text: And finally we heard 'commune', which means to get close to someone or something. For example, Rob likes to commune with nature when he goes running. He enjoys the way the landscape changes with the seasons.'

speaker: Rob
text: Well said, Catherine. Now, that's all we have time for today. But if you would like to commune with us via our Facebook, Twitter or YouTube pages, please do so.

speaker: Catherine/Rob
text: Bye!
